By Council Member Chin:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226 (g) or Section 20-225(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed/enclosed sidewalk café located at 212 Lafayette Street, Community Board 2, Application 20115530 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by Consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk café, 212 Lafayette St, Manhattan (20115530 TCM)

Items.Title:
By Council Member Garodnick:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226 (g) or Section 20-225(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed/enclosed sidewalk café located at 1022 Lexington Avenue,  Community Board 8, Application 20115128 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States House of Representatives to vote against H.R. 358, a bill which will severely restrict women's right to access abortion and endanger women's lives by permitting health care providers to deny life saving care in emergencies.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) called for a voice vote.  
Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: Council Members Halloran, Ignizio, and Koo.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Vote against H.R. 358, a bill which will severely restrict women’s right to access abortion.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States House of Representatives to vote against H.R. 3, a bill which will raise taxes on millions of Americans and severely limit women's right to access abortion services.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) called for a voice vote.  
Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) declared the Resolution to be adopted.




The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: Council Members Halloran, Ignizio, and Koo.



The following Council Member formally abstained to vote on this item: Council Member Wills.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Vote against H.R. 3, a bill which will raise taxes on millions of Americans and severely limit women’s right to access abortion services.

Items.Title: Resolution urging the United States House of Representatives to vote against H.R. 217, a bill that will restrict access to women's reproductive health services by severely restricting funding for family planning providers and the United States Senate to protect family planning funds and reject the total defunding of Planned Parenthood.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) called for a voice vote.  
Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) declared the Resolution to be adopted.




The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: Council Members Halloran, Ignizio, and Koo.

                                    .



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Vote against H.R. 217, a bill that will restrict access to women’s reproductive health services by severely restricting funding for family planning providers.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring the New York City Board of Elections to post sample ballots on its website prior to elections.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Requiring the New York City Board of Elections to post sample ballots on its website prior to elections.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the installation of detectable warning surfaces.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Requiring the installation of detectable warning surfaces.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the transfer of functions from the department of records and information services to the department of citywide administrative services, and to repeal chapter 72 of the charter concerning the department of records and information services.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Transfer of functions from the department of records and information services to the department of citywide administrative services.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Congress to pass and the President to sign into law the “Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device Act”  (H.R.308/S.32), which would prohibit the transfer or possession of large capacity ammunition feeding devices unless otherwise permissible by law.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass and the President to sign into law the “Large Capacity Ammunition Feeding Device Act”  (H.R.308/S.32)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York City Congressional Delegation and President Barack Obama to prevent cuts to the Community Services Block Grant Program.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
Items.MatterName: NYC Congressional Delegation and President Barack Obama to prevent cuts to the Community Services Block Grant Program.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to amend the Penal Law by creating the crime of aggravated criminal use of a firearm for discharging a firearm on school grounds or public park lands.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Creating the crime of aggravated criminal use of a firearm for discharging a firearm on school grounds or public park lands.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to limiting the parking of motor vehicles by dealers.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Limiting the parking of motor vehicles by dealers.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Food and Drug Administration to make “gluten-free” labeling of foods mandatory.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: United States FDA to make “gluten-free” labeling of foods mandatory.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York City Charter, in relation to records access by council members.

Items.MatterName: Records access by council members.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the New York City Police Department to report on gang-related arrests in schools.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Requiring the New York City Police Department to report on gang-related arrests in schools.

Items.Title: Resolution proclaiming that the New York City Council stands in solidarity with public workers in Wisconsin, Ohio, and in other states around the country as their struggle for dignity and economic security is one shared by all New Yorkers and Americans.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: Proclaiming that the NYC Council stands in solidarity with public workers in Wisconsin, Ohio, and in other states around the country as their struggle for dignity and economic security is one shared by all New Yorkers and Americans.

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Providing information about free foreclosure prevention assistance.

Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: NYC Dept of Health and Mental Hygiene to study the effects of fluoride in tap water.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the posting of a bond to ensure compliance with building and maintenance requirements by holders of mortgages commencing foreclosure actions.

Items.MatterName: Requiring the posting of a bond to ensure compliance with building and maintenance requirements by holders of mortgages commencing foreclosure actions.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass and the Governor to sign into law A.1306 and S.1337, in relation to requiring all passengers of motor vehicles sixteen years and older to be restrained by safety belts.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Requiring all passengers of motor vehicles sixteen years and older to be restrained by safety belts.  (A.306/S.1337)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Senate to ratify the Convention on the Rights of the Child in order to enable New York City to participate in proceedings before its monitoring body.

Items.MatterName: Senate to ratify the Convention on the Rights of the Child in order to enable NYC to participate in proceedings before its monitoring body.

Items.Title: Resolution that celebrates “Harriet Tubman Day” on March 10, 2011, and supports Senate Bill S.247, sponsored by U.S. Senators Charles Schumer (D-NY), Kirsten Gillibrand (D-NY), Benjamin Cardin (D-MD) and Barbara Mikulski (D-MD), that would create two national historic park sites in New York and Maryland, in honor of Harriet Tubman, who escaped slavery to become the most famous conductor on the Underground Railroad.
Items.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
Items.MatterName: “Harriet Tubman Day” on March 10, 2011
